div.p:
I heard from your dear
mother yesterday & hers
& your fathers opinion
of the memory were
balm to my heart

What a happiness, what a blessing it is
to our whole family my dear Francis
to have such a friend as you especial
ly especially in the present circumstances. You
have done most prudently to warn
dear Fanny not to let her hopes be
raised too high by this flattering
amendment. I take it for granted
that you have used the same precau
-tion precaution where it is far more necessary -
with Honora and my mother - Toward

As to my self I am still more inclined
to fear than hope - But I will not de-
tail detail my causes of apprehension - they
must have all occurred to your mind
& you will I am sure weigh all
things well in every step that is taken
- I must however mention one thing
of which perhaps you have not been
apprized sufficiently that L 's mind
is liable to a dangerous susceptibility
on that he was very nervous this time
last year - so much so as to think it necessa
ry necessary to consult Dr. M - On the subject of
W - he must be from previous associations
particularly irritable - and the danger of
their meeting must be reciprocally great
- To this trial however it must come soon-
er sooner or later unless - which I forbode - the
malady with fresh paroxysms returns
- you will be surprised perhaps
shocked at me my dear friend when
I tell you that considering the chances
of evil to all the family from partial
amendment I do not feel any plea-
sure pleasure from this gleam of hope - Any thing
short of perfect sound restoration such
as should enable him to pursue his
profession, live in his own country &
with his family without danger to
himself & to them I should consider
as an increase rather than a diminu
tion diminuition of the evil. - If I could look forward
to such a complete recovery - But
I cannot - The more I fear for our family, the more
strongly I feel the advantage of having
in such circumstances a friend at once
judicious, courageous & affectionate
- attached to them all & to the sufferer
more than any as much as any one
now living can be -

I have written to L & my mother
referring to your account of W. and de-
siring desiring to know their wishes
as to our returning home directly
or proceeding to Geneva as I had pro-
posed proposed to do on the 20th. of this month.
- I thought that perhaps my mother or
Lovell might wish to go to England
this before the autumn to see W.
- I shall not stir from Paris or its vici
nity (meaning the distance of a few
hours drive) till I hear from Mrs E
and I need not tell you that we shall
be guided implicitly by her wishes.

Fanny and Harriet continue to
be pleased and to please at Paris -
- Whenever I think of telling you any
thing of what we see & hear so much &
such variety crowd upon my mind
that I know not where to begin or end
To go no farther back than the two or 3 last
days - Thursday - We went to the
nation-
al national or as it is now the fashion to call it
the royal library - where M Langles
devot
-ed devoted two hours of his time to shewing us
the manuscript letters of Henry the 4th . Francis
1st . Louis 14th . and various celebrated people
and from the 500,000 volumes of which it is said
this magnificent library consists directed our
attention to what was best worth our seeing
- Through the whole changes of the revolution
Lan
gles Langles
has kept his place as librarian but once was
very near losing it when upon Bonapartes send-
ing sending him some books & Mss manuscripts pillaged from Spain &
and Italy - he observed that it would be a great
deal of waste trouble to put them into the catalogue
for that he was sure they would be afterwards
restored to their own countries - In fact 8000
volumes were restored at the peace of the Allies

After seeing the library we dined with
an amiable agreeable family of Creeds (Scotch)
he is here employed to arrange if possible
the national debt between France & England
- We dined with his family under the
trees in their garden and between 9 & 10
went to see Camille Jourdan Jordan
& took with
us M.r Creed & Malthus who is now at
Paris - Both had much wished to be made
acquainted with Camille - whose talents
and honorable conduct entitle him to the
large share of public esteem he enjoys - He is
now so much out of health that he is obliged
to lie on a sofa most of the day in the inter
vals intervals of public exertion - At his house we saw
assembled almost all the distinguished people
of the moderate liberales - And there was
Madame Recamier - a much happier woman
now she has lost her fortune & has a few
real friends attached to her by her own
good qualities than she was in the blaze
of her wealth & beauty - Malthus enjoyed
himself much - One of the greatest pleasures
which I have had at Paris has been in in-
-troducing introducing
some of our friends to each other who had
long desired to meet -

After Camille Jourdan Jordan
's we ended
the evening at the Duchesse de Clermont Ton-
-nerre Tonnerre
s all her society - Ultras - very entertaining contrast
LB French fashionable nonsense delightful ice - & fine music here -

Another day - Morning between 11 & 1 -
M.r Malthus - M.r Creed & Breguet - Breguet
explains on mechanical subjects as well as all
those do & only those who perfectly understand them - talked
with Fanny of Brown's iron chain bridge - last went
to meet us at the observatory, to introduce us
to Arrago the astronomer. - Arrago has some
- thing something in the simplicity of his & cordiality
of his manner & in his way of going straight
forward to the business of science like
our own dear D.r Brinkley - He spoke of
D.r Brinkley with the highest esteem - Thinking
him far superior to Pond in abilities &
science - yet on the question of the parallax
thinks Brinkley wrong & Pond right &
admires the ingenious mode of proof
Pond has devised - It was great pleasure
to me to see Fanny enjoy all that she saw
& heard at this observatory & to perceive
that she was appreciated - But poor W -
could not but be present to our minds
with deep regret -

Breguet has all the simplicity of
a man of great talents - He remembers
my father well & speaks of him & of my
mother with respect I might almost say
with affection that Fanny & Harriet
interest him much - we dine with him
the day after tomorrow & he has invited
Prony & others of the first scientific talent
to meet us - My dear Francis I wish you
were here - I feel as if I was taking up the place

After returning from the Observatory we
dined at Ivry a few miles from Paris
where the Duchess Dowager of Orleans lives
- (She with whom Madame de Genlis plagued)
- She is a benevolent dignified old lady
her countenance is said to resemble Lewis 14ths
Her dame d'honneur Madame de Casteras
a spanish lady who followed her in all her
misfortunes & who is a person of strong
character & warm indignation interested
as much by the strength originality of her
observations & force of her expressions -
While an Archbishop of Rheims &c &c played
at whist after dinner this lady conversed delightfully and a
Prussian French officer (name unknown)
gave us an account of the Russian cam-
paign campaign & of his own sufferings - I asked whe-
-ther whether
La Beaume's is an exaggerated ac-
count account - Not at all -

After returning from the Duchesse
d'Orleans went to Madame d'Houssonville
& enjoyed the cool breeze in the gardens
at the back of her beautiful house till be-
ween between eleven & 12 - Agreeable conversa-
-tion conversation except from a woman who has written
4 quartos on "The happiness of Nations" &
who was conceited & tiresome -

The next day we went to
Champla-
treux ChamplÃ¢treux
- the country house of Comte MolÃ©
the descendant of President MolÃ©. His fa-
ther father was guillotined - their very large property
& magnificent chateau seized as national
property - & for some years time the present Count
MolÃ© was in prison & afterward supported
his mother & sister by as he told me by the
hard work of his hands - he cooked for them
& often the very little they had to eat & often
went to bed so hungry himself that he cd not
sleep - This was when he was about 15 -
- His property was restored by a decree of the convention after Robespierres
death as was the property of almost all
those who had not emigrated - his house how
ever he found only bare walls - the magnificent
tapestry - glasses - books - all destroyed - To
speak according to their mode of describing
the house had formerly forty lits de maitre
he has restored 15 excellent bed chambers
- The principal sitting room about 40 feet
long is fitted up with every English com
fort comfort & luxury - a round library table
in the centre - plenty of tables with books
inkstands &c a piano forte - and all
things well arranged in every part
of the house so as to unite French taste
& English comfort- We have spent 4 days
at two different visits in this house &
we were very glad to see the style of
a French country house & the mode
of living - They all breakfast together
as we do - and their children breakfasted
and dined with them - When I said
that I had heard that French families
usually took coffee in their own rooms
instead of breakfasting en famille,
Ma-
dame Madame de Vintimille a lady between
50 & 60 assured me that from her childhood
in all the houses where she had been
intimate (the custom had always been
to breakfast together - Excepting at the Duc de
Choiseul's - when he was in the country
& in his famous banishment the crowds
of people at his court used to order breakfast and dinner
their own apartments or in public as they pleased - NB in the palace
were a milliners shop from which the
ladies might send for whatever they
liked - letters - washing - horses - servants
all paid for - this lasted 4 years - Every
person who went there inscribed their names
on marble tables - in a temple - which
were turned inside out afterwards in
the time of the republic -
But I must now stop abruptly
for two people are waiting for me to go to
hear mass at la chapelle du Roi.
Am I in your debt dear Francis
- tell me for I do not clearly know?
div.closer:
Ever affectionately yrs. yours
Maria E.

postscript.p:
The translation of the mem.r is going on - & going on well
we cannot yet answer your question
about Karamania - but at Briguet's dinner
shall know.
I have recommended dialogues on Botany
to many here & a lady is going to translate
it - send me any corrections or orders about it.

& notworthstanding the confusion
& haste visible in this letter
depend upon it I will find
time to execute your commands
punctually and carefully as you do for me

As this letter has been detained a day
or two I can add two or three of the 1000
things I wish to tell you.
Paris is appears perfectly quiet since the
law of election has past - But the
causes of discontent remaining & are
no moretre
ust than the
interval of silen Volcano -

The alternate of the spirit of
insurrection & frivolity is striking
- One moment we hear a Frenchman
expressing his regret that his country
cannot be free as England is - The
next moment we hear him say he
is au desespoir because he cannot
make his neat cloth sit like an
Englishman's - without in-
serting inserting some stiffening collar
which I am told spoils the effect
& is considered as a national
misfortune -

I begged my mother to transmit
to you Lorevet's last words & what
he said on his trial - As well as I recol
-lect recollect one remarkable expression was
ommitted - He said the night before his execution
"People may think it is an easy matter
to poignard a man - But I can tell them that between
" the time of drawing the dagger & plunging
" it in is an hour of horror & difficulty
"that no man can conceive beforehand"

How near this comes to Shakespeare's
Macbeth
" Between the thinking & the acting of a dreadful deed &c
